definition: A computer architecture that processes data and memory addresses that are 32 bits wide, limiting RAM to about 4 GB.
A computer architecture that processes 64-bit wide data and addresses, allowing vastly more RAM and better performance than 32-bit systems.
A Microsoft directory service that stores information about objects on a network and provides authentication and authorization.
An open-source mobile operating system developed by Google, primarily used on smartphones and tablets.
Apple’s proprietary operating system for Macintosh computers, commonly known as macOS.
A button in software interfaces used to confirm and save changes without closing the window.
A property or characteristic of a file or folder, such as read-only, hidden, or system.
A copy of data stored separately from the original to prevent loss in case of failure or corruption.
The ability of newer software or hardware to work with older versions or formats.
A Windows security feature that provides full-disk encryption to protect data from unauthorized access.
A feature of BitLocker that encrypts removable drives such as USB flash drives.
The sequence of steps a computer follows to start the operating system after being powered on.
An operating system developed by Google that is based on Linux and designed to work primarily with web applications.
A text-based interface where users type commands to interact with the operating system or applications.
A method of reducing the size of files to save storage space or speed up transfers.
A menu that appears when right-clicking an object, showing options relevant to that item.
A Windows tool that provides access to system settings and configuration options.
The main graphical workspace of an operating system where icons, files, and application windows are displayed.
A default Windows folder where users typically store personal files and documents.
The ability of a user or device to connect to and use resources in a Windows Active Directory domain.
A Windows feature that allows individual files and folders to be encrypted for security.
The point at which a product, such as software, is no longer supported or updated by the manufacturer.
Software that can be expanded or enhanced with plugins, modules, or updates.
The suffix at the end of a filename (e.g., .txt, .jpg) that indicates the file type.
The format of a file that determines how the data inside is structured and which applications can open it.
The name given to a file, often combined with an extension to identify the file type.
A container used in operating systems to organize files and other folders.
The ability of older software or hardware to function in newer environments.
A visual way of interacting with a computer using windows, icons, and menus instead of text commands.
A small graphical symbol that represents a program, file, or function on the desktop or interface.
The process of cataloging files and their contents to speed up search operations in an operating system.
Apple’s proprietary mobile operating system for iPhones and some iPads.
Apple’s mobile operating system designed specifically for iPads, based on iOS with added features.
A collection of related files and folders in Windows that appear as a single virtual location.
An open-source operating system kernel used in many distributions such as Ubuntu and Fedora.
Apple’s current operating system for Macintosh computers, successor to OS X.
A widely used proprietary operating system developed by Microsoft for PCs.
A system of interconnected computers and devices that share resources and communicate with each other.
The section of the Windows taskbar that displays system and application icons, such as clock, volume, and background apps.
Software with source code made available for anyone to view, modify, and distribute.
An operating system owned by a company that restricts use, modification, or distribution.
The maximum amount of memory an operating system or architecture can use effectively.
A storage device that contains tools to troubleshoot, repair, or reinstall an operating system.
A Windows feature that temporarily stores deleted files until permanently removed or restored.
The Windows Registry Editor tool used to view and modify the system registry.
The process of reinstalling an operating system to fix problems or restore it to default state.
A potential danger that could exploit vulnerabilities in software, hardware, or networks.
A link that points to a file, folder, or application for quick access.
A situation where a program does not function correctly because of conflicts with other software or the operating system.
A button in Windows used to access the Start menu and launch applications.
The full-screen menu in Windows 8 that displayed tiles for applications and settings.
A directory within another directory used to organize files in a hierarchical structure.
A folder within another folder used for file organization.
A complete backup of a computer’s operating system, programs, and files.
A Windows feature that allows users to view all open windows and manage virtual desktops.
A bar typically at the bottom of the screen in Windows that displays open applications and shortcuts.
A Windows interface that shows drives, folders, and system locations on the computer.
A graphical element in Windows that represents an application or shortcut, often on the Start menu or screen.
The ability of a system or program to take advantage of features in newer versions while still working correctly.
A collection of personal settings, files, and preferences associated with a specific user account.
A Microsoft operating system released in 2015 with features such as Cortana, virtual desktops, and the Start menu.
Microsoft’s latest operating system released in 2021, featuring a redesigned interface and enhanced productivity tools.
A recovery platform included with Windows that provides tools to troubleshoot, repair, or restore the system.
